Images.Name: i0
Images.Description: 15-Plex Orion Image of Tonsil Lymphoid Hyperplasia

Header:
This is a whole-slide tissue section of a tonsil with reactive lymphoid hyperplasia stained with a 15-plex biomarker panel and imaged with the Orion system in a single staining and scanning process.  Images in this presentation show subsets of markers that have been selected from the larger immuno-oncology panel.

Cancer tissue micro-environments contain numerous cell types, including epithelial, immune, vascular endothelial and smooth muscle cells in a spatial context for immune response. 

In tonsil, B cell follicles (CD20) with germinal centers and T cell interfollicular zones (CD4) define the lymphoid compartment that is lined by epithelial crypts (Pan-CK and E-Cadherin), which are invaginations of the squamous mucosa of the pharynx.

Waypoints.Name: Cell proliferation in the follicle
Waypoints.Description:
The follicle is the micro-anatomic site of clonal expansion of B cells in response to foreign antigens. In reactive lymphoid tissues, they are enlarged and have distinct compartments, including a highly proliferative germinal center and a surrounding mantle zone.

Germinal centers are clearly visualized by Ki67 and PCNA which are markers of cellular proliferation. Many orange-yellow staining cells are present indicating co-expression of both markers within the cell nucleus. Nuclear staining (Hoechst) demonstrates the mantle zone, surrounding the germinal center, that contains small, densely-packed cells. 

Macrophages (CD68) eliminate apoptotic B cells and. are found interspersed within the germinal center.

Waypoints.Name: T cells in the follicle
Waypoints.Description:
Helper T cells (CD4) participate in the activation of B cell (CD20) expansion.  Numerous helper T cells can be seen in the germinal center, with some seen in the mantle zone.  Within the mantle zone scattered cytotoxic T cells (CD8a) are also present. 

Spatial multiplexing demonstrates that the immune checkpoint receptor PD-1 is distinctly expressed by CD4 helper T cells within the germinal center in this field, but not in helper T cells in the T cell zone, and not in CD8 cytotoxic T cells.

Waypoints.Name: PD-L1 Expression
Waypoints.Description:
PD-L1 and PD-1 are cognate immune checkpoint receptors involved in tumor evasion of the immune system, and their expression on tumor cells and within the tumor microenvironment impacts response to checkpoint inhibitor therapy.

PD-L1 expression is present at high levels in the tonsillar crypt
epithelium (Pan-CK), at moderate levels in follicle germinal centers (CD20) to the left of the crypt, and at low levels in stromal cells of the T cell zone, shown above the germinal center.

Waypoints.Name: Memory cells in the follicle
Waypoints.Description:
Memory lymphocytes can be identified by the marker CD45RO. 

In the follicle most of the memory cells co-express CD45RO and CD4, indicating that they are helper T cells.  

Numerous memory helper T cells can be seen in the T cell zone, as well as CD4 cells that are CD45RO negative.

Most B cells (CD20) are negative for CD45RO. This is most clearly seen in the mantle zone.

Waypoints.Name: Lymphocyte trafficking in the high endothelial venule (HEV)
Waypoints.Description:
Recirculation of lymphocytes into lymphoid tissues occurs via the HEV: vessels specialized for the attachment and transmigration of circulating cells.  They are present in the T cell zone and contain characteristic endothelial cells (CD31) with ample cytoplasm.

Shown within the HEV are:

• CD4 T cells (including FoxP3 T regulatory cells)
• CD8 T cells
• CD20 B cells within the lumen of the HEV in longitudinal section 

FoxP3 is localized to the nucleus and can also be seen in many CD4 cells in the T cell zone surrounding the vessel.

Waypoints.Name: Macrophage Subsets
Waypoints.Description:
Macrophages can express different markers depending on their function, which may be mapped spatially to location within a tissue.

In the follicle, germinal center macrophages express CD68. Just outside the follicle in the T cell zone, HEV (CD31) macrophages express both CD163 and CD68. 

Macrophages have processes that extend beyond the cell body.  When these are cut in cross-section and stained the resulting image may appear as a point or wispy fragment.
